trans-unit.source: This sample will guide you through elements of the F# language.
trans-unit.target: This sample will guide you through elements of the F# language.

trans-unit.source: To execute the code in F# Interactive, highlight a section of code and press Alt-Enter or right-click
trans-unit.target: To execute the code in F# Interactive, highlight a section of code and press Alt-Enter or right-click

trans-unit.source: and select "Execute in Interactive". You can open the F# Interactive Window from the "View" menu.
trans-unit.target: and select "Execute in Interactive". You can open the F# Interactive Window from the "View" menu.

trans-unit.source: For additional templates to use with F#, see the 'Online Templates' in Visual Studio,
trans-unit.target: For additional templates to use with F#, see the 'Online Templates' in Visual Studio,

trans-unit.source: 'New Project' --> 'Online Templates'
trans-unit.target: 'New Project' --> 'Online Templates'

trans-unit.source: F# supports three kinds of comments:
trans-unit.target: F# supports three kinds of comments:

trans-unit.source: 1. Double-slash comments. These are used in most situations.
trans-unit.target: 1. Double-slash comments. These are used in most situations.

trans-unit.source: 2. ML-style Block comments. These aren't used that often.
trans-unit.target: 2. ML-style Block comments. These aren't used that often.

trans-unit.source: 3. Triple-slash comments. These are used for documenting functions, types, and so on.
trans-unit.target: 3. Triple-slash comments. These are used for documenting functions, types, and so on.

trans-unit.source: They will appear as text when you hover over something which is decorated with these comments.
trans-unit.target: They will appear as text when you hover over something which is decorated with these comments.

trans-unit.source: They also support .NET-style XML comments, which allow you to generate reference documentation,
trans-unit.target: They also support .NET-style XML comments, which allow you to generate reference documentation,

trans-unit.source: and they also allow editors (such as Visual Studio) to extract information from them.
trans-unit.target: and they also allow editors (such as Visual Studio) to extract information from them.

trans-unit.source: To learn more, see: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/articles/fsharp/language-reference/xml-documentation
trans-unit.target: To learn more, see: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/articles/fsharp/language-reference/xml-documentation

trans-unit.source: Open namespaces using the 'open' keyword.
trans-unit.target: Open namespaces using the 'open' keyword.

trans-unit.source: To learn more, see: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/articles/fsharp/language-reference/import-declarations-the-open-keyword
trans-unit.target: To learn more, see: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/articles/fsharp/language-reference/import-declarations-the-open-keyword

trans-unit.source: A module is a grouping of F# code, such as values, types, and function values.
trans-unit.target: A module is a grouping of F# code, such as values, types, and function values.

trans-unit.source: Grouping code in modules helps keep related code together and helps avoid name conflicts in your program.
trans-unit.target: Grouping code in modules helps keep related code together and helps avoid name conflicts in your program.

trans-unit.source: To learn more, see: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/articles/fsharp/language-reference/modules
trans-unit.target: To learn more, see: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/articles/fsharp/language-reference/modules

trans-unit.source: Values in F# are immutable by default. They cannot be changed
trans-unit.target: Values in F# are immutable by default. They cannot be changed

trans-unit.source: in the course of a program's execution unless explicitly marked as mutable.
trans-unit.target: in the course of a program's execution unless explicitly marked as mutable.

trans-unit.target: To learn more, see: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/articles/fsharp/language-reference/values/index#why-immutable

trans-unit.source: Binding a value to a name via 'let' makes it immutable.
trans-unit.target: Binding a value to a name via 'let' makes it immutable.

trans-unit.source: The second line of code fails to compile because 'number' is immutable and bound.
trans-unit.target: The second line of code fails to compile because 'number' is immutable and bound.

trans-unit.source: Re-defining 'number' to be a different value is not allowed in F#.
trans-unit.target: Re-defining 'number' to be a different value is not allowed in F#.

trans-unit.source: A mutable binding. This is required to be able to mutate the value of 'otherNumber'.
trans-unit.target: A mutable binding. This is required to be able to mutate the value of 'otherNumber'.

trans-unit.source: When mutating a value, use '<-' to assign a new value.
trans-unit.target: When mutating a value, use '<-' to assign a new value.

trans-unit.target: You could not use '=' here for this purpose since it is used for equality

trans-unit.target: or other contexts such as 'let' or 'module'

trans-unit.target: Much of F# programming consists of defining functions that transform input data to produce

trans-unit.source: useful results.
trans-unit.target: useful results.

trans-unit.source: You use 'let' to define a function. This one accepts an integer argument and returns an integer.
trans-unit.target: You use 'let' to define a function. This one accepts an integer argument and returns an integer.

trans-unit.source: Parentheses are optional for function arguments, except for when you use an explicit type annotation.
trans-unit.target: Parentheses are optional for function arguments, except for when you use an explicit type annotation.

trans-unit.source: Apply the function, naming the function return result using 'let'.
trans-unit.target: Apply the function, naming the function return result using 'let'.

trans-unit.source: The variable type is inferred from the function return type.

trans-unit.source: This line uses '%d' to print the result as an integer. This is type-safe.
trans-unit.target: This line uses '%d' to print the result as an integer. This is type-safe.

trans-unit.source: If 'result1' were not of type 'int', then the line would fail to compile.
trans-unit.target: If 'result1' were not of type 'int', then the line would fail to compile.

trans-unit.source: When needed, annotate the type of a parameter name using '(argument:type)'. Parentheses are required.
trans-unit.target: When needed, annotate the type of a parameter name using '(argument:type)'. Parentheses are required.

trans-unit.source: Conditionals use if/then/elid/elif/else.
trans-unit.target: Conditionals use if/then/elid/elif/else.

trans-unit.source: Note that F# uses whitespace indentation-aware syntax, similar to languages like Python.
trans-unit.target: Note that F# uses whitespace indentation-aware syntax, similar to languages like Python.

trans-unit.source: Booleans are fundamental data types in F#. Here are some examples of Booleans and conditional logic.

trans-unit.source: To learn more, see:
trans-unit.target: To learn more, see:

trans-unit.source: and
trans-unit.target: and

trans-unit.source: Booleans values are 'true' and 'false'.
trans-unit.target: Booleans values are 'true' and 'false'.

trans-unit.source: Operators on booleans are 'not', '&&' and '||'.
trans-unit.target: Operators on booleans are 'not', '&&' and '||'.

trans-unit.source: This line uses '%b'to print a boolean value. This is type-safe.
trans-unit.target: This line uses '%b'to print a boolean value. This is type-safe.

trans-unit.source: Strings are fundamental data types in F#. Here are some examples of Strings and basic String manipulation.
trans-unit.target: Strings are fundamental data types in F#. Here are some examples of Strings and basic String manipulation.

trans-unit.source: To learn more, see: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/articles/fsharp/language-reference/strings
trans-unit.target: To learn more, see: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/articles/fsharp/language-reference/strings

trans-unit.source: Strings use double quotes.
trans-unit.target: Strings use double quotes.

trans-unit.source: Strings can also use @ to create a verbatim string literal.
trans-unit.target: Strings can also use @ to create a verbatim string literal.

trans-unit.source: This will ignore escape characters such as '\', '\n', '\t', etc.
trans-unit.target: This will ignore escape characters such as '\', '\n', '\t', etc.

trans-unit.source: String literals can also use triple-quotes.
trans-unit.target: String literals can also use triple-quotes.

trans-unit.source: String concatenation is normally done with the '+' operator.
trans-unit.target: String concatenation is normally done with the '+' operator.

trans-unit.source: This line uses '%s' to print a string value. This is type-safe.
trans-unit.target: This line uses '%s' to print a string value. This is type-safe.

trans-unit.source: Substrings use the indexer notation. This line extracts the first 7 characters as a substring.
trans-unit.target: Substrings use the indexer notation. This line extracts the first 7 characters as a substring.

trans-unit.source: Note that like many languages, Strings are zero-indexed in F#.
trans-unit.target: Note that like many languages, Strings are zero-indexed in F#.

trans-unit.source: Tuples are simple combinations of data values into a combined value.
trans-unit.target: Tuples are simple combinations of data values into a combined value.

trans-unit.source: To learn more, see: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/articles/fsharp/language-reference/tuples
trans-unit.target: To learn more, see: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/articles/fsharp/language-reference/tuples

trans-unit.source: A simple tuple of integers.
trans-unit.target: A simple tuple of integers.

trans-unit.target: F# Type Inference will automatically generalize the function to have a generic type,

trans-unit.source: meaning that it will work with any type.
trans-unit.target: meaning that it will work with any type.

trans-unit.source: Type annotations for tuples use the * symbol to separate elements
trans-unit.target: Type annotations for tuples use the * symbol to separate elements

trans-unit.source: Tuples are normally objects, but they can also be represented as structs.
trans-unit.target: Tuples are normally objects, but they can also be represented as structs.

trans-unit.source: These interoperate completely with structs in C# and Visual Basic.NET; however,
trans-unit.target: These interoperate completely with structs in C# and Visual Basic.NET; however,

trans-unit.source: struct tuples are not implicitly convertable with object tuples (often called reference tuples).
trans-unit.target: struct tuples are not implicitly convertable with object tuples (often called reference tuples).

trans-unit.source: Given a list of integers, it filters out the even numbers,
trans-unit.target: Given a list of integers, it filters out the even numbers,

trans-unit.source: squares the resulting odds, and adds 1 to the squared odds.
trans-unit.target: squares the resulting odds, and adds 1 to the squared odds.

trans-unit.source: A shorter way to write 'squareOddValuesAndAddOne' is to nest each
trans-unit.target: A shorter way to write 'squareOddValuesAndAddOne' is to nest each

trans-unit.source: sub-result into the function calls themselves.
trans-unit.target: sub-result into the function calls themselves.

trans-unit.source: This makes the function much shorter, but it's difficult to see the
trans-unit.target: This makes the function much shorter, but it's difficult to see the

trans-unit.source: order in which the data is processed.
trans-unit.target: order in which the data is processed.

trans-unit.source: A preferred way to write 'squareOddValuesAndAddOne' is to use F# pipe operators.
trans-unit.target: A preferred way to write 'squareOddValuesAndAddOne' is to use F# pipe operators.

trans-unit.source: This allows you to avoid creating intermediate results, but is much more readable
trans-unit.target: This allows you to avoid creating intermediate results, but is much more readable

trans-unit.source: than nesting function calls like 'squareOddValuesAndAddOneNested'
trans-unit.target: than nesting function calls like 'squareOddValuesAndAddOneNested'

trans-unit.target: You can shorten 'squareOddValuesAndAddOnePipeline' by moving the second `List.map` call

trans-unit.target: Note that pipelines are also being used inside the lambda function. F# pipe operators

trans-unit.target: Lastly, you can eliminate the need to explicitly take 'values' in as a parameter by using '>>'

trans-unit.source: to compose the two core operations: filtering out even numbers, then squaring and adding one.

trans-unit.target: Likewise, the 'fun x -> ...' bit of the lambda expression is also not needed, because 'x' is simply

trans-unit.target: being defined in that scope so that it can be passed to a functional pipeline. Thus, '>>' can be used

trans-unit.source: Lists are ordered, immutable, singly-linked lists. They are eager in their evaluation.
trans-unit.target: Lists are ordered, immutable, singly-linked lists. They are eager in their evaluation.

trans-unit.source: This module shows various ways to generate lists and process lists with some functions
trans-unit.target: This module shows various ways to generate lists and process lists with some functions

trans-unit.source: in the 'List' module in the F# Core Library.
trans-unit.target: in the 'List' module in the F# Core Library.

trans-unit.target: To learn more, see: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/articles/fsharp/language-reference/lists

trans-unit.source: Lists are defined using [ ... ]. This is an empty list.
trans-unit.target: Lists are defined using [ ... ]. This is an empty list.

trans-unit.source: This is a list with 3 elements. ';' is used to separate elements on the same line.
trans-unit.target: This is a list with 3 elements. ';' is used to separate elements on the same line.

trans-unit.source: You can also separate elements by placing them on their own lines.
trans-unit.target: You can also separate elements by placing them on their own lines.

trans-unit.target: This is a list of integers from 1 to 1000

trans-unit.target: Lists can also be generated by computations. This is a list containing

trans-unit.target: all the days of the year.

trans-unit.source: Arrays are fixed-size, mutable collections of elements of the same type.
trans-unit.target: Arrays are fixed-size, mutable collections of elements of the same type.

trans-unit.source: Although they are similar to Lists (they support enumeration and have similar combinators for data processing),
trans-unit.target: Although they are similar to Lists (they support enumeration and have similar combinators for data processing),

trans-unit.source: they are generally faster and support fast random access. This comes at the cost of being less safe by being mutable.
trans-unit.target: they are generally faster and support fast random access. This comes at the cost of being less safe by being mutable.

trans-unit.source: To learn more, see: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/articles/fsharp/language-reference/arrays
trans-unit.target: To learn more, see: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/articles/fsharp/language-reference/arrays

trans-unit.source: This is The empty array. Note that the syntax is similar to that of Lists, but uses `[| ... |]` instead.
trans-unit.target: This is The empty array. Note that the syntax is similar to that of Lists, but uses `[| ... |]` instead.

trans-unit.source: Arrays are specified using the same range of constructs as lists.
trans-unit.target: Arrays are specified using the same range of constructs as lists.

trans-unit.source: This is an array of numbers from 1 to 1000.
trans-unit.target: This is an array of numbers from 1 to 1000.

trans-unit.source: This is an array containing only the words "hello" and "world".
trans-unit.target: This is an array containing only the words "hello" and "world".

trans-unit.source: This is an array initialized by index and containing the even numbers from 0 to 2000.
trans-unit.target: This is an array initialized by index and containing the even numbers from 0 to 2000.

trans-unit.source: Sub-arrays are extracted using slicing notation.
trans-unit.target: Sub-arrays are extracted using slicing notation.

trans-unit.source: You can loop over arrays and lists using 'for' loops.
trans-unit.target: You can loop over arrays and lists using 'for' loops.

trans-unit.source: You can modify the contents of an an array element by using the left arrow assignment operator.
trans-unit.target: You can modify the contents of an an array element by using the left arrow assignment operator.

trans-unit.target: To learn more about this operator, see: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/articles/fsharp/language-reference/values/index#mutable-variables

trans-unit.source: The following calculates the sum of the lengths of the words that start with 'h'.
trans-unit.target: The following calculates the sum of the lengths of the words that start with 'h'.

trans-unit.source: Sequences are a logical series of elements, all of the same type. These are a more general type than Lists and Arrays.
trans-unit.target: Sequences are a logical series of elements, all of the same type. These are a more general type than Lists and Arrays.

trans-unit.source: Sequences are evaluated on-demand and are re-evaluated each time they are iterated.
trans-unit.target: Sequences are evaluated on-demand and are re-evaluated each time they are iterated.

trans-unit.source: An F# sequence is an alias for a .NET System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable<'T>.
trans-unit.target: An F# sequence is an alias for a .NET System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable<'T>.

trans-unit.source: Sequence processing functions can be applied to Lists and Arrays as well.
trans-unit.target: Sequence processing functions can be applied to Lists and Arrays as well.

trans-unit.source: To learn more, see: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/articles/fsharp/language-reference/sequences
trans-unit.target: To learn more, see: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/articles/fsharp/language-reference/sequences

trans-unit.source: This is the empty sequence.
trans-unit.target: This is the empty sequence.

trans-unit.source: This a sequence of values.
trans-unit.target: This a sequence of values.

trans-unit.source: This is an on-demand sequence from 1 to 1000.
trans-unit.target: This is an on-demand sequence from 1 to 1000.

trans-unit.source: This is a sequence producing the words "hello" and "world"
trans-unit.target: This is a sequence producing the words "hello" and "world"

trans-unit.source: This sequence producing the even numbers up to 2000.
trans-unit.target: This sequence producing the even numbers up to 2000.

trans-unit.source: This is an infinite sequence which is a random walk.
trans-unit.target: This is an infinite sequence which is a random walk.

trans-unit.source: This example uses yield! to return each element of a subsequence.
trans-unit.target: This example uses yield! to return each element of a subsequence.

trans-unit.source: This example shows the first 100 elements of the random walk.
trans-unit.target: This example shows the first 100 elements of the random walk.

trans-unit.source: Recursive functions can call themselves. In F#, functions are only recursive
trans-unit.target: Recursive functions can call themselves. In F#, functions are only recursive

trans-unit.source: when declared using 'let rec'.

trans-unit.source: Recursion is the preferred way to process sequences or collections in F#.

trans-unit.source: Discriminated Unions (DU for short) are values which could be a number of named forms or cases.
